body: @JulySouthWind By adding `-L/data2/opencv/opencv-2.4/build/lib`, you tell compiler where to find the opencv libraries. But you also need to tell compiler which libraries to link, like `-lopencv_calib3d -lopencv_contrib -lopencv_core -lopencv_features2d`

Yes, you could use `mxnet.io.NDArrayIter`. First load your data to a numpy array (or mxnet ndarray). Then feed it to a `mxnet.io.NDArrayIter`. You could then use it with your model in mxnet.

You can compile package without OpenMP on your own machine.

Since only the CPU-version of pre-built package is provided, personally I think it is better to have OpenMP in it.
Gottcha, it's probably better to mention these in the build doc as R users typically don't have much experience on that.

For the first question, I think it is fine for your current setting. One thing I would suggest is to compress your data. If your data is highly compressable (like text), you could save a lot of space and maybe you could put all the data on each machine then. Basically, you pay the cost of decompression to the disk space which seems to be precious in your setting.

For the second question, a quick (and hacky) way is to
1. Calculate validation metrics on each machine (result is a real number).
2. Write the result to a shared file (maybe on NFS).
3. Read them on the first machine.
4. Sum them up and report.
It's probably also worth mentioning blog posts like this: https://medium.com/@lelayf/installing-mxnet-for-r-on-yosemite-291470055980#.3j69s3hbd

I'm afraid you need to write your own code in `im2rec` to do this. If I do not understand it wrong, what you need is an extra int for each image that represents how many labels it has. So you need to modify the code to put this information together with the label information.

One hacky way I could think about within the current fixed-num-label setting is that you could encode the number of labels as part of labels. For example, suppose your `image.lst` file is like this:

```
path_to_img1 1
path_to_img2 3
path_to_img3 23
...
```

You could add another column to specify the number of labels.

```
path_to_img1 1 5
path_to_img2 3 5
path_to_img3 23 7
...
```

When using `img2rec`, use `label_width=2` to read the file.

@vchuravy gotcha. I think within current framework, what we could do is to implement two special dataflow operators: one for MPISend, one for MPIRecv. But this is only the first step. For MPIRecv task, there is no upstream task so it (and its memory space) will be created and stay there for a long time. One way to deal with it is the technique mentioned in tensorflow paper that delay the schedule of MPIRecv task until MPISend task is launched.

#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Template configuration for compiling mxnet
#
#  If you want to change the configuration, please use the following
#  steps. Assume you are on the root directory of mxnet. First copy the this
#  file so that any local changes will be ignored by git
#
#  $ cp make/config.mk .
#
#  Next modify the according entries, and then compile by
#
#  $ make
#
#  or build in parallel with 8 threads
#
#  $ make -j8
#-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

#---------------------
# choice of compiler
#--------------------
export CC = clang
export CXX = clang++
export NVCC = nvcc

# whether compile with debug
DEBUG = 0

# the additional link flags you want to add
ADD_LDFLAGS = '-L/usr/local/opt/openblas/lib' '-L/usr/local/cuda/lib'  '-L/usr/local/cudnn/lib'

# the additional compile flags you want to add
ADD_CFLAGS = '-I/usr/local/opt/openblas/include' '-I/usr/local/cuda/include'   '-I/usr/local/cudnn/include'

# per https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/728#issuecomment-160867057
 ADD_LDFLAGS += -Xlinker -F/Library/Frameworks -Xlinker -framework -Xlinker CUDA

#---------------------------------------------
# matrix computation libraries for CPU/GPU
#---------------------------------------------

# whether use CUDA during compile
USE_CUDA = 1

# add the path to CUDA libary to link and compile flag
# if you have already add them to enviroment variable, leave it as NONE
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda
# USE_CUDA_PATH = NONE

# whether use CUDNN R3 library
USE_CUDNN = 1

# whether use opencv during compilation
# you can disable it, however, you will not able to use
# imbin iterator
USE_OPENCV = 1

# use openmp for parallelization
USE_OPENMP = 0

# choose the version of blas you want to use
# can be: mkl, blas, atlas, openblas
USE_BLAS = openblas

# add path to intel libary, you may need it for MKL, if you did not add the path
# to enviroment variable
USE_INTEL_PATH = NONE

#----------------------------
# distributed computing
#----------------------------

# whether or not to enable mullti-machine supporting
USE_DIST_KVSTORE = 0

# whether or not allow to read and write HDFS directly. If yes, then hadoop is
# required
USE_HDFS = 0

# path to libjvm.so. required if USE_HDFS=1
LIBJVM=$(JAVA_HOME)/jre/lib/amd64/server

# whether or not allow to read and write AWS S3 directly. If yes, then
# libcurl4-openssl-dev is required, it can be installed on Ubuntu by
# sudo apt-get install -y libcurl4-openssl-dev
USE_S3 = 0
